title: Characterization of Stainless Steel Percutaneous Leads Exposed to Common Environmental Solutions
content: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) can provide selective stimulation to a nerve to restore motor function in weak or paralyzed muscles or activate sensory fascicles to evoke a perceived sensation from amputated limbs [1-3]. To deliver this type of therapy, electronics ranging from electrodes and leads to power and recording modules may be implanted subcutaneously connecting to the muscle and/or nerves. Some system architectures utilize peripheral nerve cuff electrodes that also rely on connection to an external stimulator requiring percutaneous leads to cross through the dermis [1,3]. For these systems, the components must be biocompatible, resistant to mechanical damage, and maintain appropriate electrical functionality [2].
